castItem.role: ANTIPHO,From a)nti\, "opposite to," and fw=s, "light," or fh=mi, "to speak."
GETA,One of the nation of the Getae.
DAVUS,From Dacia, his native country; the Davi and Daci being the same people.
HEGIO,From h(gei=sqai, "to lead," or "take charge of." Advocates.
DORIO,From Doris, his country, a part of Caria.
NAUSISTRATA,From nau=s, "a ship," and strato\s, "an army."

body.p: Scene.--Athens; before the houses of DEMIPHO, CHREMES, and DORIO.

div2.head: THE SUBJECT.
div2.p: CHREMES and DEMIPHO are two aged Athenians, brothers. Nausistrata, the wife of Chremes, is a wealthy woman, possessed of large estates in the island of Lemnos. Chremes, who goes thither yearly to receive the rents, meets with a poor woman there, whom he secretly marries, and has by her a daughter called Phanium: while engaged in this intrigue, Chremes passes at Lemnos by the name of Stilpho. By his wife, Nausistrata, at Athens, Chremes has a son, named Phaedria, and his brother has a son, named Antipho. Phanium having now arrived at her fifteenth year, the two brothers privately agree that she shall be brought to Athens and married to Antipho. For this purpose, Chremes goes to Lemnos, while Demipho is obliged to take a journey to Cilicia. On departing, they leave their sons in the care of Geta, one of Demipho's servants. Shortly afterward, Phaedria falls in love with a Music-girl, but, from want of means, is unable to purchase her from her owner. In the mean time, the Lemnian wife of Chremes, urged by poverty, embarks for Athens, whither she arrives with her daughter and her nurse. Here they inquire for Stilpho, but in vain, as they can not find any one of that name. Shortly after, the mother dies, and Antipho, seeing Phanium by accident, falls in love with her. Being wishful to marry her, he applies to Phormio, a Parasite, for his advice. The latter hits upon the following scheme: there being a law at Athens, which obliges the next-of-kin to female orphans, either to marry them or give them a portion, the Parasite pretends that he is a friend of Phanium, and insists that Antipho is her nearest relation, and is consequently bound to marry her. Antipho is summoned before a court of justice, and it being previously arranged, allows judgment to be given against himself, and immediately marries Phanium. Shortly after, the old men return upon the same day, and are much vexed, the one on finding that his son has married a woman without a fortune, the other that he has lost the opportunity of getting his daughter advantageously married. In the mean time, Phaedria being necessitated to raise some money to purchase the Music-girl, Geta and Phormio arrange that the former shall pretend to the old man that Phormio has consented to take back the woman whom Antipho has married, if Demipho will give her a portion of thirty mine. Demipho borrows the money of Chremes, and pays it to Phormio, who hands it over to Phaedria, and Phaedria to Dorio, for his mistress. At this conjuncture, it becomes known who Phanium really is, and the old men are delighted to find that Antipho has married the very person they wished. They attempt, however, to get back the thirty minae from Phormio, and proceed to threats and violence. On this, Phormio, who has accidentally learned the intrigue of Chremes with the woman of Lemnos, exposes him, and relates the whole story to his wife, Nausistrata; on which she censures her husband for his bad conduct, and the Play concludes with her thanks to Phormio for his information.

div2.head: THE TITLE OF THE PLAY.
div2.p: PERFORMED at the Roman Games,The Roman Games)--The "ludi Romani," or "Roman Games," were first established by Ancus Marcius, and were celebrated in the month of September. L. Posthumius Albinus and L. Cornelius Merula being Curule Aediles. L. Ambivius Turpio and L. Atilius Praenestinus performed it. Flaccus, the freedman of Claudius, composed the music to a base and a treble flute. It is wholly from the Greek, being the Epidicazomenos of Apollodorus. It was represented four times,Four times)--The numerals signifying "four," Donatus takes to mean that this was the fourth Play composed by Terence; it is, however, more generally supposed that the meaning is, that it was acted four times in one year. C. Fannius and M. Valerius being Consuls.Being Consuls)--M. Valerius Messala and C. Fannius Strabo were Consuls in the year from the Building of the City 591, and B.C. 162.

div2.head: THE SUMMARY OF C. SULPITIUS APOLLINARIS.
div2.p: DEMIPHO, the brother of Chremes, has gone abroad, his son Antipho being left at Athens. Chremes has secretly a wife and a daughter at Lemnos, another wife at Athens, and an only son, who loves a Music-girl. The mother arrives at Athens from Lemnos, and there dies. The girl, her orphan daughter, (Chremes being away,) arranges the funeral. After Antipho has fallen in love with her when seen there, through the aid of the Parasite he receives her as his wife. His father and Chremes, having now returned. begin to be enraged. Afterward they give thirty minae to the Parasite, that he may take her as his own wife. With this money the Music-girl is bought for Phoedria. Antipho then keeps his wife, who has been recognized by his uncle.

sp.speaker: THE PROLOGUE.
sp.p: SINCE the old PoetSince the old Poet: He alludes to his old enemy, Luscus Lavinius, who is mentioned in all his Prologues, except those to the Hecyra. can not withdraw our bard from his pursuits and reduce him to indolence, he endeavors, by invectives, to deter him from writing: for he is wont to say to this effect,--that the Plays which he has hitherto composed are poor in their language, and of meagre style; because he has nowhere described a frantic youth as seeing a hind in flight, and the hounds pursuing; while he imploresWhile one implored)--Ver. 8. "Et eam plorare, orare ut subveniat sibi." This is probably in allusion to some absurd passage in one of the Plays of Lavinius. It is generally supposed to mean, that the stag implores the young man; but as the youth is mad, the absurdity of the passage is heightened if we suppose that he implores the stag, and, in the moment of its own danger, entreats it to come to his own assistance; as certainly the Latin will admit of that interpretation.--Ovid has a somewhat similar passage in the Pontic Epistles, B. ii. Ep. ii. 1. 39: "The hind that, in its terror, is flying from the savage dogs, hesitates not to trust itself to the neighboring house." and entreated that he would give her aid. But if he had been aware that his Play, when formerly first represented, stood its ground more through the merits of the performers than its own, he would attack with much less boldness than he does. Now, if there is any one who says or thinks to this effect, that if the old Poet had not assailed him first, the young one could have devised no Prologue for him to repeat, without having some one to abuse, let him receive this for an answer: "that the prize is proposed in common to. all who apply to the Dramatic art." He has aimed at driving our Poet from his studies to absolute want; he then has in-tended this for an answer, not an attack. If he had opposed him with fair words, he would have heard himself civilly addressed; what has been given by him, let him consider as now returned. I will make an end of speaking about him, when, of his own accord, he himself makes an end of offending. Now give your attention to what I request. I present you a new Play, which they call "Epidicazomenos,"Epidicazomenos: A Play of Apollodorus, so called from that Greek word, signifying "one who demands justice from another," in. allusion to Phormio, who is the complainant in the suit, which is the foundation of the plot. in Greek: in the Latin, he calls it "Phormio;" because the person that acts the principal part is Phormio, a Parasite, through whom, principally, the plot will be' carried on, if your flavor attends the Poet. Lend your attention; in silence give an ear with impartial feelings, that we may not experience a like fortune to what we did, when, through a tumult, our Company was driven from the place;Was driven from the place: Alluding, probably, to the disturbances which took place at the first representation of the Hecyra, and which are mentioned in the Prologues to that Play. which place, the merit of the actor, and your good-will and candor seconding it, has since restored unto us.

div2.stage: Enter DAVUS,Davus is a protatic character, only introduced for the purpose of opening the story. with a bag of money in his hand.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Geta, my very good friend and fellow-townsman, came to me yesterday. There had been for some time a trifling balance of money of his in my hands upon a small account; he asked me to make it up. I have done so, and am carrying it to him. But I hear that his master's son has taken a wife; this, I suppose, is scraped together as a present for her. How unfair a custom!--that those who have the least should always be giving something to the more wealthy! That which the poor wretch has with difficulty spared, ounce by ounce, out of his allowance,Out of his allowance: Donatus tells us that the slaves received four "modii," or measures of corn, each month, which was called their "demensum." defrauding himself of every indulgence, the whole of it will she carry of, without thinking with how much labor it has been acquired. And then besides, Geta will be struckWill be struck: "Ferietur." "To strike" a person for a present was said when it was extorted from him reluctantly. So in the Trinummuns of Plautus, 1. 247, "Ibi illa pendentem ferit." "Then does she strike while he is wavering." for another presentFor another present: Presents were usually made to persons on.their birthday, on the day of their marriage, and on the birth of their children. when his mistress is brought to bed; and then again for another present, when the child's birthday comes; when they initiate him,Initiate him: It is not known what initiation is here referred to. Madame Dacier thinks it was an initiation into the great mysteries of Ceres, which was commonly performed while children were yet very young; others suggest that it means the period of weaning the child, and initiating it into the use of another kind of diet. Donatus says, that Varro speaks of children being initiated into the mysteries of the Deities Edulia, Potica, and Cuba, the Divinities of Eating, Drinking, and Sleeping. too: all this the mother will carry off; the child will only be the pretext for the present. But don't I see Geta there?

div2.stage: Enter GETA, from the house of DEMIPHO.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: at the door, to those within. If any red-haired man should inquire for me----

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: stepping forward. Here he is, say no more.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: starting. Oh! Why I was trying to come and meet you, Davus.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: giving the money to GETA. Here, take it; it's all ready counted out;Ready counted out: "Lectum," literally "picked out" or "chosen"--the coins being of full weight. the number just amounts to the sum I owed you.'

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I am obliged to you; and I return you thanks for not having forgotten me.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Especially as people's ways are nowadays; things are come to such a pass, if a person repays you any thing, you must be greatly obliged to him. But why are you out of spirits?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What, I? You little know what terror and peril I am in.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: GETA.
sp.p: You shall know, if you can only keep it secret.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Out upon you, simpleton; the man, whose trustworthiness you have experienced as to money, are you afraid to intrust with words? In what way have I any interest in deceiving you?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Well then, listen.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I give you my best attention.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Davus, do you know Chremes, the elder brother of our old gentleman?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Why should I not?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Well, and his son Phaedria?

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: As well as your own self.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: It so happened to both the old gentlemen, just at the same period, that the one had to take a journey to Lemnos, and our old man to Cilicia, to see an old acquaintance; he tempted over the old man by letters, promising him all but mountains of gold.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: To one who had so much property, that he had more than he could use?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Do have done; that is his way.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Oh, as for that, I really ought to have been a man of fortune.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: When departing hence, both the old gentlemen left ne as a sort of tutor to their sons.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Ah, Geta, you undertook a hard task there.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I came to experience it, I know that. I'm quite sure that I was forsaken by my good Genius, who must have been angry with me.Have been angry with me: le alludes to the common belief that each person had a Genius or Guardian Deity; and that when misfortune overtook him, he had been abandoned by his Genius. I began to oppose them at first; but what need of talking? As long as I was trusty to the old men, I was paid for it in my shoulder-blades. This, then, occurred to my mind: why, this is folly to kick against the spur.Kick against the spur: "To kick against the pricks," or "in spite of the spur," was a common Greek proverb.--The expression occurs in the New Testament, Acts ix. 5. "It is hard for thee to kick against the pricks." I began to do every thing for them that they wished to be humored in.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: You knew how to make your market.To make your market: This is a metaphorical expression taken from traffic, in which merchants suit themselves to the times, and fix a price on their commodities, according to the course of the market.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Our young fellow did no mischief whatever at first; that Phaedria at once picked up a certain damsel, a Music-girl, and fell in love with her to distraction. She belonged to a most abominable Procurer; and their fathers had taken good care that they should have nothing to give him.. There remained nothing for him then but to feed his eyes, to follow her about, to escort her to the school,To the school: It was the custom for the "lenones," or "procurers," to send their female slaves to music-schools, in order to learn accomplishments. So in the Prologue to the Rudens of Plautus: "This Procurer brought the maiden to Cyrene hither. A-certain Athenian youth, a citizen of this city, beheld her as she was going home from the music-school." and to escort her back again. We, having nothing to do, lent our aid to Phaedria. Near the school at which she was taught, right opposite the place, there was a certain barber's shop: here we were generally in the habit of waiting for her, until she was coming home again. In the mean time, while one day we were sitting there, there came in a young man in tears;Young man in tears)--Ver. 92. In the Play of Apollodorus, it was the barber himself that gave the account how he had just returned from cutting off the young woman's hair, which was one of the usual ceremonies in mourning among the Greeks. Donatus remarks, that Terence altered this circumstance that he might not shock a Roman audience by a reference to manners so different from their own. we were surprised at this. We inquired what was the matter? "Never," said he, "has poverty appeared to me a burden so grievous and so insupportable as just now. I have just seen a certain poor young woman in this neighborhood lamenting her dead mother. She was laid out before her, and not a single friend, acquaintance, or relation was there with her, except one poor old woman, to assist her in the funeral: I pitied her. The girl herself was of surpassing beauty." What need of a long story? She moved us all. At once Antipho exclaims, "Would you like us to go and visit her?" The other said, "I think awe ought--let us go--show us the way, please." We went, and arrived there; we saw her; the girl was beautiful, and that you might say so the more, there was no heightening to her beauty; her hair disheveled, her feet bare, herself neglected, and in tears; her dress:mean, so 'that, had there not been an excess of beauty in her very charms, these circumstances must have extinguished those charms. The one who had lately fallen in love with the Music-girl said: "She is well enough;" but our youth----

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I know it already-fell in love with her.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Can you imagine to what an extent? Observe the consequence. The day after, he goes straight to the old woman; entreats her to let him have her: she, on the other hand, refuses him, and says that he is not acting properly; that,she is a citizen of Athens, virtuous, and born of honest parents: that if he wishes to make her his wife, he is at liberty to do so according to law; but if otherwise, she gives him a refusal. Our youth was at a loss what to. do. He was both eager to marry her, and he dreaded his absent father.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Would not his father, if he had returned, have given him leave?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He let him marry a girl with no fortune, and of obscure birth! He would never do so.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What came of it at last?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What came of it? There is one Phormio here, a Parasite, a fellow of great assurance; may all the Gods confound him!

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He has given this piece of advice, which I will tell you of. "There is a law, that orphan girls are to marry those who are their next-of-kin; and the same law commands such persons to marry them. I'll say you are the next-of-kin, and take out a summonsTake out a summons: "Dica" was the writ or summons with which an action at law was commenced. against you; I'll pretend that I am a friend of the girl's father; we will come before the judges: who her father was, who her mother, how she is related to you--all this I'll trump up, just as will be advantageous and suited to my purpose; on your disproving none of these things, I shall prevail, of course. Your father will return; a quarrel will be the consequence; what care I? She will still be ours."

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: An amusing piece of assurance!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He was, persuaded to this. It was carried out; they came into court: we were beaten. He has married her.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What is it you tell me?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Just what you have heard.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: 0 Geta, what will become of you?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Upon my faith, I don't know; this one thing I do know, whatever fortune may bring, I'll bear it with firmness.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: You please me; well, that is the duty of a man.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: All my hope is in myself.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: I commend you.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Suppose I have recourse to some one to intercede for me, who will plead for: me in these terms: "Pray, do forgive him this time; but if after this he does any thing, I make no entreaty:" if only he doesn't add, "When I've gone, e'en kill him for my part."

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: What of the one who was usher to the Music-girl?Usher to the Music-girl)-- Ver. 144. This is said satirically of Phaedria, who was in the habit of escorting the girl to the music-school. It was the duty of the "paedagogi," or "tutors," to lead the children to school, who were placed under their care. See the speech of Lydus, the paedagogus of Pistoclerus, in the Bacchides of Plautus, Act iii. Sc. 3, where, enlarging upon his duties, he mentions this among them.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: shrugging his shoulders. So so, but poorly.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Perhaps he hasn't much to give.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Why, really, nothing at all, except mere hopes.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Is his father come back or not?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Well, when do you expect your old man?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I don't know for certain; but I just now heard that a letter has been brought from him, and has been left with the officers of the customs: I'm going to fetch it.

sp.speaker: DAVUS
sp.p: Is there any thing else that you want with me, Geta?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Nothing, but that I wish you well. Exit DAVUS. Hark you, boy calling at the door. Is nobody coming out here? A LAD comes out. Take this, and give it to Dorcium. He gives the purse to the LAD, who carries it into DEMIPHO'S house and exit GETA.

div2.stage: Enter ANTIPHO and PHAEDRIA.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: That things should have come to such a pass, Phaedria, that I should be in utter dread ,of my father, who wishes me so well, whenever his return comes into my thoughts! Had I not been inconsiderate, I might have waited for him, as I ought to have done.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Do you ask the question? You, who have been my confederate in so bold an adventure? How I do wish it had never entered the mind of Phormio to persuade me to this, or to urge me in the heat of my passion to this step, which is the source of my misfortunes. Then I should not have obtained her; in that case I might have been uneasy for some few days; but still, this perpetual anxiety would not have been tormenting my mind touching PHAEDRIA.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I hear you.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: While I am every moment expecting his return, who is to sever from me this connection.Sever from me this connection)--Ver. 161. By forcing him to divorce her.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Other men feel uneasiness because they can not gain what they love; you complain because you have too much. You are surfeited with love, Antipho. Why, really, upon my faith, this situation of yours is surely one to be coveted and desired. So may the Gods kindly bless me, could I be at liberty to be so long in possession of the object of my love, I could contentedly die. Do you, then, form a judgment as to the rest, what I am now suffering from this privation, and what pleasure you enjoy from the possession of your desires; not to mention how, without any expense, you have obtained a well-born and genteel woman, and have got a wife of unblemished reputation: happy you, were not this one thing wanting, a mind capable of bearing all this with moderation. If you had to deal with that Procurer with whom I have to deal, then you would soon be sensible of it. We are mostly all of us inclined by nature to be dissatisfied with our lot.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Still, on the other hand, Phadria, you now seem to me the fortunate man, who still have the liberty, without restraint, of resolving on what pleases you best: whether to keep, to love on, or to give her up. I, unfortunately, have got my-self into that position, that I have neither rightNeither right)--Ver, 176. No right to get rid of her in consequence of the judgment which, at the suit of Phormio, has been pronounced against him; nor yet, right to keep her, because of his father insisting upon turning her out of doors. to give her up, nor liberty to retain her. But how's this? Is it our Geta I see running this way? 'Tis he himself. Alas! I'm dreadfully afraid what news it is he's now bringing me.

div2.stage: Enter GETA, running, at the other side of the stage.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself. Geta, you are undone, unless you instantly find out some expedient; so suddenly do such mighty evils now threaten me thus unprepared, which I neither know how to shun, nor how to extricate myself therefrom; for this daring step of:ours can not now any longer be kept a secret. If such a result is not adroitly guarded against, these matters will cause the ruin of myself, or of my master.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: to PHAEDRIA. Why, I wonder, is he coming in such fright?:

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself. Besides, I've but a moment left for this matter--my master's close at hand.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: to PHAEDRIA. What mischief is this?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself. When he comes to hear of it, what remedy shall I discover for his anger Am I to speak? I shall irritate him: be silent? I shall provoke him: excuse myself? I should be washing a brickbat.Be washing a brickbat)-- Ver. 187. "Laterem lavare," "to wash a brick,"' or "tile," was a proverb signifying labor in vain, probably because (if the brick was previously baked) it was impossible to wash away the red color of it. According to some, the saying alluded to the act of washing a brick which had been only dried in the sun, in which case the party so doing both washed away the brick and soiled his own fingers. Alas! unfortunate me! While I am trembling for myself, this Antipho distracts my mind. I am concerned for him; I'm in dread for him: 'tis he that now keeps me here; for had it not been for him, I should have made due provision for my safety, and have taken vengeance on the old man for his crabbedness; I should have scraped up something, and straightway taken to my heels away from here.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: to PHAEDRIA. I wonder What running away or theft it is that he's planning.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself. But where shall I find Antipho, or which way go look for him?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: to ANTIPHO. He's mentioning your name.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: to PHADRIA. I know not what great misfortune I expect to hear from this messenger.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: to ANTIPHO. Why, are you in your senses?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself. I'll make my way homeward; he's generally there.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: to ANTIPHO. Let's call the fellow back.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: calling out. Stop, this instant.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: turning round. Heyday--with authority enough, whoever you are.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Geta!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: The very person I wanted to find.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Pray, tell me what news you bring, and dispatch it in one word, if you can.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I'll do so.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Out with it.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Just now, at the harbor----

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What, my father?----

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: You've hit it.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: . Ruined outright!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What am I to do?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: to GETA. What is it you say?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: That I have seen his father, your uncle.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: How am I, wretch that I am, now to find a remedy for this sudden misfortune? But if it should be my fortune, Phanium, to be torn away from you, life would cease to be desirable.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Therefore, Antipho, since matters are thus, the more need have you to be on your guard; fortune helps the brave.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I am not myself.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: But just now it is especially necessary you should be so, Antipho; for if your father perceives that you are alarmed, he will think that you have been guilty of sone fault.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: That's true.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I can not change.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What would you do, if now something else still more difficult had to be done by you?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: As I am not equal to this, I should be still less so to the other.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: This is doing nothing at all, Phaedria, let's be gone; why do we waste our time here to no purpose. I shall be off.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: And I too. They move as if going.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Pray, now, if I assume an air, will that do? He endeavors to assume another air.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: You are trifling.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Look at my countenance--there's for you. Assuming a different air. Will that do?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Well, will this? Assuming another air.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Pretty well.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Well then, this? Assuming a still bolder air.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: That's just the thing. There now, keep to that, and answer him word for word, like for like; don't let him, in his anger, disconcert you with his blustering words.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Say that you were forced against your will by law, by sentence of the court; do you take me? Looking earnestly in one direction. But who is the old man that I see at the end of the street?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: 'Tis he himself. I can not stand it. Going.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Oh! What are you about? Whither are you going, Antipho? Stop, I tell you.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I know my own self and my offense; to your management I trust Phanium and my own existence. (Exit hastily.)

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Geta, what's to be done now?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: You will just hear some harsh language: I shall be trussed up and trounced, if I am not somewhat mistaken. But what we were just now advising Antipho to do, the same we must do ourselves, Phaedria.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Away with your "musts;" rather do you command me what I am to do.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: DO you remember what were your words formerly on our entering upon this project, with the view of protecting yourselves from ill consequences--that their cause was just, clear, unanswerable, and most righteous?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I remember it.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Well then, now there's need of that plea, or of one still better and more plausible, if such there can be.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I'll use my best endeavors.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Do you then accost him first; I'll be here in re-serve,Here in reserve)--Ver. 230. "Succenturiatus." The "succenturiati" were, properly, men intrusted to fill up vacancies in the centuries or companies, when thinned by battle. by way of reinforcement, if you give ground at all.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Very well. They retire to a distance.

div2.stage: Enter DEMIPHO, at the other side of the stage.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to himself. And is it possible that Antipho has taken a wife without my consent? and that no authority of mine--but let alone "authority"Let alone "authority" "Ac mitto imperium." Cicero has quoted this passage in his Epistles to Atticus, B. ii. Ep. 19.--no displeasure of mine, at all events, has he been in dread of? To have no sense of shame! O audacious conduct! O Geta, rare adviser!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart to PHAEDRIA. Just brought in at last.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What will they say to me, or what excuse will they find? I wonder much.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. Why, I've found that out already; do think of something else.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Will he be saying this to me: "I did it against my will; the law compelled me?" I hear you, and admit it.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. Well said!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: But knowingly, in silence, to give up the cause to his adversaries--did the law oblige him to do that as well?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. That is a hard blow.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I'll clear that up; let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: It is a matter of doubt what I am to do; for beyond expectation, and quite past all belief, has this befallen me. So enraged am I, that I can not compose my mind to think upon it. Wherefore it is the duty of all persons, when affairs are the most prosperous,When affairs are the most prosperous)--Ver. 241. Cicero quotes this passage in the Third Book of his Tusculan Questions, and the maxim here inculcated was a favorite one with the Stoic philosophers. then in especial to reflect within themselves in what way they are to endure adversity. Returning from abroad, let him always picture to himself dangers and losses, either offenses committed by a son, or the death of his wife, or the sickness of a daughter,--that these things are the common lot, so that no one of them may ever come as a surprise upon his feelings. Whatever falls out beyond his hopes, all that he must look upon as so much gain.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. O Phaedria, it is incredible how much I surpass my master in wisdom. All my misfortunes have been already calculated upon by me, upon my master coming home. I must grind at the mill, be beaten, wear fetters, be set to work in the fields; not one individual thing of these will happen unexpected by my mind. Whatever falls out beyond my expectations, all that I shall look upon as so much gain. But why do you hesitate to accost him, and soften him at the outset with fair words? PHAEDRIA goes forward to accost DEMIPHO.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to himself. I see Phaedria, my brother's son, coming toward me.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: My uncle, welcome!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Greetings to you; but where is Antipho?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: That you have arrived in safety----

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I believe it; answer my question.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: He is well; he's close at hand; but is every thing quite to your wishes?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I wish it was so, indeed.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Do you ask me, Phaedria? You people have cooked up a fine marriage in my absence.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What now, are you angry with him for that?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. What a clever contriver!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Have I not reason to be angry with him? I long for him to come into my sight, that he may know that through his faultiness, from being a mild father, I am become a most severe one.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: But he has done nothing, uncle, for which you should blame him.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Now, do look at that; all alike; all hanging together; when you know one, you know all.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: That is not the case.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: When the one is in fault, the other is at hand to defend him; when it is the other, then he is ready; they just help one another by turns.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. The old man, without. knowing it, has exactly described their proceedings.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: For if it had not been so, you would not, Phaedria, have stood up for him.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: If, uncle; it is the fact, that Antipho has been guilty of any fault, in consequence of which he has been too regardless of his interest or his reputation, I would not allege any reason why he should not suffer what he deserves. But if some one by chance, relying upon his own artfulness, has laid a snare for our youthful age, and has succeeded, is it our fault or that of the judges, who often, through envy, take away from the rich, or, through compassion, award to the poor?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. Unless I knew the case, I could fancy he was saying the truth.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Is there any judge who can possibly know your rights, when you yourself don't answer a word--as he has done?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: He acted the part of an ingenuous young man; after they had come before the judges, he was not able to say what he had intended, so much did his modesty confuse him there through his bashfulness.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. I commend him: but why do I hesitate at once to accost the old man? Going forward to DEMIPHO. Master, welcome to you! I'm glad to see you safe returned.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: ironically. Ah, excellent guardian! save you, stay of my family, no doubt, to whom, at my departure, I intrusted my son.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: For some minutes past I've heard you accusing all of us undeservedly; and me the most undeservedly of them all; for what would you have had me do for you in this affair? The laws do not allow a person who is a slave to plead; nor is there any giving evidenceAny giving evidence)--Ver. 293. Slaves were neither allowed to plead for themselves, nor to give evidence. See the Curculio of Plautus, 1. 621, and the Notes to the Andria. on his part.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I grant all that: I admit this too--the young man, unused to courts, was bashful; I allow it: you, too, are a slave: still, if she was ever so near a relative, it was not necessary for him to marry her, but as the law enjoins, you might have given her a portion;Given her a portion)--Ver. 297. By this remark, Donatus observes that Terence artfully prepares us for the imposition of Phormio, who extorts money fiom the old gentleman on this very ground. she could have looked out for another husband. Why, then, in preference, did he bring a pauper home?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: No particular reason; but he hadn't the money.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: He might have borrowed it from some person or other.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: From some person or other? Nothing more easily said.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: After all, if on no other terms, on interest.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Aye, aye, fine talking; as if any one would have trusted him, while you were living.While you were living)--Ver. 302. There was a law at Athens which enacted that persons who lent money to young men in the lifetime of their parents should have no power to recover it. In line 303 of the Pseudolus, Plautus alludes to the Quinavicenarian or Laetorian Law, at Rome, which forbade credit to be given to persons under the age of twenty-five years, and deprived the creditor of all right to recover his money or goods.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: No, it shall not be so; it must not be. Ought I to allow her to remain with him as his wife a single day? She merits no indulgence. I should like this fellow to be pointed out to me, or to be shown where he lives.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Phormio, do you mean?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: That fellow, the woman's next friend?The woman's next friend)--Ver. 307. The "patronus" was the person who undertook to conduct a lawsuit for another.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I'll have him here immediately.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Where is Antipho at present?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Away from home.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Go, Phedria, look for him, and bring him here.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I'Il go straightway to the place.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: aside. To Pamphila, you mean. (Exeunt PHAEDRIA and GETA.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to himself. I'll just step home to salute the house-hold Gods.Salute the household Gods)--Ver. 311. It was the custom for those returning from a voyage or journey, to give thanks to their household Gods for having protected them in their absence. Thus, in the Amphitryon of Plautus, Jupiter, while personating Amphitryon, pretends, in 1. 983, that he is going to offer sacrifice for his safe return. From there, I'll go to the Forum, and summon some of my friends to give me their assistance in this affair; so that I may not be unprepared, when Phormio comes. Goes into his house.

div2.stage: Enter PHORMIO and GETA.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: And so you sayAnd so you say)--Ver. 315. Donatus tells the following story with reference to this passage: "This Play being once rehearsed before Terence and some of his most intimate acquaintances, Ambivius, who acted the part of Phormio, came in drunk, which threw the author into a violent passion; but Ambivius had scarcely repeated a few lines, stammering and scratching his head, before Terence became pacified, declaring that when he was writing these very lines, he had exactly such a Parasite as Ambivius then represented, in his thoughts." that, dreading his father's presence, he has taken himself off?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Exactly so.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: That Phanium is left alone?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: And that the old man is in a rage?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Extremely so.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: The whole business, Phormio, rests on yourself alone; you yourself have hashed it up;Have hashed it up)--Ver. 318. He is thought to allude here, figuratively, to the composition of a dish called "moretum," (in praise of which Virgil wrote a poem,) which was composed of garlic, onions, cheese, eggs, and other ingredients, beaten up in a mortar. The allusion to eating is appropriately used in an address to a Parasite. it must all be swallowed by yourself, so set about it.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I entreat you----

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to himself. If he inquires.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: In you is all our hope.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to himself. Look at this, now:--What if he sends her back?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: It was you that urged us.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to himself. I think that will do.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Do help us.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: with alacrity. Let the old gentleman come; all my plans are now ready prepared in my mind.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: What would you have me? But that Phanium may continue with him, and that I may clear Antipho from this charge, and turn upon myselfTurn upon myself)--Ver. 323. Donatus observes that in this Scene Terence exhibits the lower order of Parasites, who ingratiated themselves by sharping and roguery, as in the Eunuchus he describes Parasites of a higher rank, and of a-newer species, who obtained their ends by flattery. all the wrath of the old gentleman?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: O brave and kind man! But, Phormio, I often dread lest this courage may end in the stocks at last.In the stock at last)--Ver. 325. "In nervum; crumpat denique." There are several interpretations suggested for these words. Some think they allude to the drawing of a bow till it breaks; but they are more generally thought to imply termination in corporal punishment. "Nervus" is supposed to have been the name of a kind of stocks used in torturing slaves, and so called from being formed, in part at least, of the sinews of animals.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Oh, by no means; I've made trial, and have already pondered on the paths for my feet. How many men before to-day do you suppose I have beaten, even to death, strangers as well as citizens: the better I understand it, the oftener I try it. Just tell me, look you, did you ever hear of an action of damages being brought against me?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Because the net is never spread for the hawk or the kite, that do us the mischief; it is spread for those that do us none: because in the last there is profit, while with the others it is labor lost.- For persons, out of whom any thing can be got, there's risk from others; they know that I've got nothing. You will say: "They will take you,They will take you)--Ver. 334. At Rome, insolvent debtors became the slaves of their creditors till their debts were paid. when sentenced, into their house;" they have no wish to maintain a devouring fellow; and, in my opinion, they are wise, if for an injury they are unwilling to return the highest benefits.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: It's impossible that sufficient thanks can be returned you by him for your kindness.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Why no; no person can return thanks sufficient to his patronTo his patron)--Ver. 338. "Regi." The Parasites were in the habit of calling their patron "Rex," their "King." for his kindness. For you to take your place at table at free cost,At free cost)--Ver. 339. "Asymbolum." Without having paid his "symbola," or "club," for the entertainment. Donatus informs us that the whole of this passage is borrowed from one of Ennius, which is still preserved. anointed and just washed at the bath, with your mind at ease, whereas he is devoured with the care and expense: while every thing is being done to give you delight, he is being vexed at heart; you are laughing away, first to drink,First to drink)--Ver. 342. To be the first to drink, and to take the higher place on the couch when eating, was the privilege of the most honored guests, who usually bathed, and were then anointed before the repast. take the higher place; a banquet full of doubtsBanquet full of doubts)--Ver. 342. "Coena dubia." Horace, who borrows many of his phrases from Terence, uses the same expression. is placed before you----

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What is the meaning of that expression?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: When you are in doubt which in especial to par-take of. When you enter upon a consideration how delicious these things are, and how costly they are, the person who provides them, must you not account him a very God--neither more nor less?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: The old man is coming; take care what you are about; the first onset is the fiercest; if you stand that, then, afterward, you may play just as you please. They retire to a distance.

div2.stage: Enter, at a distance, DEMIPHO, HEGIO, CRATINUS, and CRITO, following him.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well now--did you ever hear of an injury being done to any person in a more affronting manner than this has to me? Assist me, I do beg of you.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. He's in a passion.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: apart. Do you mind your cue; I'll rouse him just now. Stepping forward and crying aloud. Oh immortal Gods! does Demipho deny that Phanium here is related to him?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He does deny it.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to his friends. I believe it is the very man I was speaking about. Follow me. They all come forward.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to GETA. And that he knows who her father was?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He does deny it.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: And that he knows who Stilpho was?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He does deny it.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Because the poor thing was left destitute, her father is disowned; she herself is slighted: see what avarice does.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: in a loud voice. If you are going to accuse my: master of avarice, you shall hear what you won't like.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Oh, the impudence of the fellow! Does he come on purpose to accuse me?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: For really, I have no reason why I should be offended at the young man, if he did not know him; since that person, when growing aged and poor, and supporting himself by his labor, generally confined himself to the country; there hehad a piece of land from my father to cultivate; full oft, in the mean time, did the old. man tell me that this kinsman of his neglected him: but what a man? The very best I ever saw in all my life.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: in a loud voice. Look to yourself as well as to him, how you speak.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: with affected indignation. Away, to utter perdition, with you. For if I had not formed such an opinion of him, I should never have incurred such enmity with your family on her account, whom he now slights in such an ungenerous manner.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: aloud. What, do you persist in speaking abusively of my master in his absence, you most abominable fellow?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Why, it's just what he deserves.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: aloud. Say you so, you jail-bird?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: calling aloud. Geta!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: aloud. A plunderer of people's property--a perverter of the laws!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: calling aloud. Geta!

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: apart, in a low voice. Answer him.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Who is it? Looking round. Oh!----

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He has never left off uttering abuse against you behind your back, unworthy of you, and just befitting himself.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well now, have done. Addressing PHORMIO. Young man, in the first place, with your good leave, I ask you this, if you may possibly be pleased to give me an answer: explain to me who this friend of yours was, that you speak of, and how he said that he was related to me.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: sneeringly. You are fishing it out, just as if you didn't know.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I, know?

sp.speaker: PEM.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I say I do not; you, Who affirm it, recall it to my recollection.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Come now, didn't you know your own cousin-ger-man?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: You torture me to death; tell me his name.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Of course. PHORMIO hesitates. Why are you silent now?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: aside. Heavens, I'm undone; I've forgot the name.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well, what do you say?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: aside, to GETA. Geta, if you recollect the name I told you a short time since, prompt me. Aloud, to DEMIPHO. Well then, I sha'n't tell you; as if you didn't know, you come to pump me.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I, come to pump you, indeed?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: whispering to PHORMIO. Stilpho.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: But, after all, what matters that to me? It is Stilpho.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Whom did you say?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Stilpho, I tell you; you knew him.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I neither know him, nor had I ever any relation of that name.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Say you so? Are you not ashamed of this? But if he had left you ten talents----

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: May the Gods confound you!

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: You'd have been the first, from memory, to trace your line of kindred, even as far back as from grandfather and great-grandfather.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Very likely what you say. In that case, when I had undertaken it, I should have shown how she was related to me; do you do the same: tell me, how is she related to me?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Well done, my master, that's right! Threateningly to PHORMIO. Hark you, take you care.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: I've already made the matter quite plain where I ought, before the judges; besides, if it was untrue, why didn't your son disprove it?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Do you talk about my son to me? Of whose folly there is no speaking in the language it deserves.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Then do you, who are so wise, go to the magistrates, that for you they may give a second decision in the same cause, since you reign aloneSince you reign alone)--Ver. 605. This is a remark well put into the mouth of an Athenian, as the public were very jealous of any person becoming paramount to the laws, and to prevent it, were frequently guilty of the most odious oppression. here, and are the only man allowed to get a second trial in the same cause.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Although wrong has been done me, still, however, rather than engage in litigation, or listen to you, just as though she had been my relation, as the law orders one to find her a portion, rid me of her, and take five minae.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: laughing.) Ha, ha, ha! a pleasant individual!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well! am I asking any thing unfair? Or am I not to obtain even this, which is my right at common law?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Pray, really is it so, that when you have abused-her like a courtesan, the law orders you to pay her hire and pack her off? Or is it the fact, that in order that a citizen may bring no disgrace upon herself through poverty, she has been ordered to be given to her nearest relative, to pass her life with him alone? A thing which you mean to prevent.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Yes, to her nearest.relative, indeed; but why to us, or on what ground?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Well, well, a thing tried, they say, you can't try over again.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Not try it? On the contrary, I shall not desist until I have gone through with it.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: You are trifling.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Only let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: In short, Demipho, I have nothing to do with you; your son has been cast, and not you; for your time of life for marrying has now gone by.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Consider that it is he that says to you all I now say, or else assuredly, together with this wife of his, I'll be forbidding him the house.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: aside. He's in a passion.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: You'll be acting more considerately.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Are you so resolved, you unlucky fellow, to do me all the mischief you can?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: aside, to GETA. He's afraid of us, although he's so careful to conceal it.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: aside, to PHORMIO. Your beginning has turned out well.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: But if, on the contrary, you endure what must be endured, you'll be doing what's worthy of you, so that we may be on friendly terms.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: indignantly. What, I seek your friendship, or have any wish to see or hear you?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: If you can agree with her, you will have some one to cheer up your old age; just consider your time of life.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Let her cheer up yourself; keep her to yourself.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Really, do moderate your passion.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Mark what I say. There have been words enough already; if you don't make haste to fetch away the woman, I shall turn her out: I have said it, Phormio.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: If you use her in any other manner than is befitting a free-born woman, I shall be bringing a swinging action against you: I have said it, Demipho. To GETA. Hark you, if there should be any occasion for me, I shall be at home.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. I understand you. (Exit PHORMIO.)

div2.stage: DEMIPHO, HEGIO, CRATINUS, CRITO, and GETA.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What care and anxiety my son does bring upon me, by entangling himself and me in this same marriage! And he doesn't so much as come into my sight, that at least I might know what he says about this matter. or what his sentiments are. To GETA. Be off, go see whether he has returned home or not by this.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I will. Goes into the house.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to the ASSISTANTS. You see how the case stands. What am I to do? Tell me, Hegio.

sp.speaker: HEGIO
sp.p: What, I? I think Cratinus ought, if it seems good to you.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Tell me, Cratinus.

sp.speaker: CRATINUS
sp.p: What, do you wish me to speak? I should like you to do what is most for your advantage; it is my opinion, that what this son of yours has done in your absence, in law and justice ought to be annulled; and that you'll obtain redress. That's my opinion.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Say now, Hegio.

sp.speaker: HEGIO
sp.p: I believe that he has spoken with due deliberation; but it is the fact, "as many men, so many minds;"So many minds)--Ver. 454. "Quot homines, tot sententiae." This is a famous adage. One similar to the succeeding one is found in the Second Eclogue of Virgil, 1. 65: "Trahit sua quemque voluptas," exactly equivalent to our saying, "Every man to his taste." every, one his own way. It doesn't appear to me that what has been done by law can be revoked; and it is wrong to attempt it.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Speak, Crito.

sp.speaker: CRITO
sp.p: I am of opinion that we must deliberate further;Must deliberate further)--Ver. 457. "Amplius deliberandum." This is probably a satirical allusion to the judicial system of procrastination, which, by the Romans, was called "ampliatio." When the judges could not come to a satisfactory conclusion about a cause, they signified it by the letters N. L. (for "non liquet," "it is not clear"), and put off the suit for a rehearing. it is a, matter of importance.

sp.speaker: HEGIO
sp.p: Do you want any thing further with us?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p:
You have done very well. Exeunt ASSISTANTS. I am much more at a lossMuch more at a loss)--Ver. 459. See the Poenulus of Plautus, where advocates or assistants are introduced among the Dramatic Personae. Colman has the following remarks on this quaint passage: "I believe there is no Scene in Comedy more highly seasoned with the ridiculous than this before us. The idea is truly comic, and it is worked up with all that simplicity and chastity so peculiar to the manner of Terence. An ordinary writer would have indulged himself in twenty little conceits on this occasion; but the dry gravity of Terence infinitely surpasses, as true humor, all the drolleries which, perhaps, even those great masters of Comedy, Plautus or Molière, might have been tempted to throw out. It is the highest art of a Dramatic Author, on some occasions, to leave a good deal to the Actor; and it has been remarked by Heinsius and others, that Terence was particularly attentive to this circumstance." than before.
Re-enter GETA, from the house.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: They say that he has not come back.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I must wait for my brother. The advice that he gives me about this matter, I shall follow. I'll go make inquiry at the harbor, when he is to come back. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: And I'll go look for Antipho, that he may learn what has passed here. But look, I see him coming this way, just in the very nick of time.

div2.stage: Enter ANTIPHO, at a distance.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: to himself. Indeed, Antipho, in many ways you are to be blamed for these feelings; to have thus run away, and intrusted your existence to the protection of other people. Did you suppose that others would give more attention to your interests than your own self? For, however other matters stood, certainly you should have thought of her whom you have now at home, that she might not suffer- any harm in consequence of her confiding in you, whose hopes and resources, poor thing, are all now centred in yourself alone.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: coming forward. Why really, master, we have for some time been censuring you here in your absence, for having thus gone away.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: You are the very person I was looking for.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: But still, we were not a bit the more remiss on that account.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Tell me, I beg of you, in what posture are my interests and fortunes. Has my father any suspicion?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Not any at present.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Is there still any hope?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: But Phaedria has not neglected to use his endeavors in your behalf.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: He did nothing new.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Then Phormio, too; in this matter, just as in every thing else, showed himself a man of energy.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What did he do?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: With his words he silenced the old man, who was very angry.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Well done, Phormio!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I, too, did all I could.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: My dear Geta, I love you all.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: The commencement is just in this position, as I tell you: matters, at present; are going on smoothly, and your father intends to wait for your uncle till he arrives.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Why him?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He said he was wishful to act by his advice, in all that relates to this business.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: How greatly now, Geta, I do dread my uncle's safe arrival! For, according to his single sentence, from what I hear, I am to live or die.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Here comes Phaedria.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Where is he, pray?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: See, he's coming from his place of exercise.From his place of exercise: "Palaestra." He alludes to the Procurer's house under this name.

div2.stage: Enter from DORIO'S house, DORIO, followed by PHAEDRIA.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Prithee, hear me, Dorio.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: I'll not hear you.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Only a moment.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Do hear what I have to say.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Why really I am tired of hearing the same thing a thousand times over.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: But now, I have something to tell you that you'll hear with pleasure.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Speak then; I'm listening.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Can I not prevail on you to wait for only three days? Whither are you going now?

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: I was wondering if you had any thing new to offer.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart, to GETA. I'm afraid for this Procurer, lest--

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart, to ANTIPHO. Something may befall his own safety.Befall his own safety)--Ver. 490. Overhearing Phedria earnest and determined, and the Procurer obstinate and inflexible, Antipho and Geta join in -apprehending that the brutality of the latter may provoke Phaedria to some act of violence.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You don't believe me?

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: You guess right.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: But if I pledge my word.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Nonsense!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You will have reason to say that this kindness was well laid out by you on interest.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Stuff!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Believe me, you will be glad you did so; upon my faith, it is the truth.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Mere dreams!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Do but try; the time is not long.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: The same story over again.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You will be my kinsman, my father, my friend; you----

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Now, do prate on.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: For you to be of a disposition so harsh and inexorable, that neither by pity nor by entreaties can you be softened!

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: For you to be of a disposition so unreasonable and so unconscionable, Phadria, that you can be talking me over with fine words,With fine words)--Ver. 499. "Phaleratis dictis." "Phalerae" were, properly, the silver ornaments with which horses were decked out, and being only for show, and not for use, gave rise to this saying. "Ductes" was an obscene Word, and not likely to be used by any but such characters as Dorio. and be for amusing yourself with what's my property for nothing!

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart, to GETA. I am sorry for him.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: aside. Alas! I feel it to be too true.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart, to ANTIPHO. How well each keeps up to his character!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: to himself. And would that this misfortune had not befallen me at a time when Antipho was occupied with other cares as well.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: coming forward. Ah Phaedria, why, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: O most fortunate Antipho!

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: To have in your possession the object of your love, and have no occasion to encounter such a nuisance as this.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What I, in my possession? Why yes, as the saying is, I've got a wolf by the ears;A wolf by the ears: A proverbial expression which, according to Suetonius, was frequently in the mouth of Tiberius Caesar. for I neither know how to get rid of her, nor yet how to keep her.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: That's just my case with regard to him pointing to PHAEDRIA.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: to DORIO. Aye, aye, don't you show too little of the Procurer. To PHAEDRIA. What has he been doing?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What, he? Acting the part of a most inhuman fellow; been and sold my Pamphila.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What! Sold her?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Sold her, say you?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Sold her.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: ironically. What a shocking crime--a wench bought with one's own money!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I can not prevail upon him to wait for me the next three days, and so far break off the bargain with the person, while I get the money from my friends, which has been promised me; if I don't give it him then, let him not wait a single hour longer.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: It's not a long time that he asks, Dorio; do let him prevail upon you; he'll pay you two-fold for having acted to him thus obligingly.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Mere words!

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Will you allow Pamphila to be carried away from this place? And then, besides, can you possibly allow their love to be severed asunder?

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Neither I nor you cause that.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: May all the Gods grant you what you are deserving of!

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: I have borne with you for several months quite against my inclination; promising and whimpering, and yet bringing nothing; now, on the other hand, I have found one to pay, and not be sniveling; give place to your betters.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I' faith, there surely was a day named, if I remember right, for you to pay him.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: It is the fact.

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Do I deny it?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Is that day past, then?

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: No; but this one has come before it.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Are you not ashamed of your perfidy?

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Not at all, so long as it is for my interest.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Dunghill!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Dorio, is it right, pray, for you to act thus?

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: It is my way; if I suit you, make use of me.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Do you try to trifle with him pointing to PHAEDRIA in this manner?

sp.speaker: DORIO
sp.p: Why really, on the contrary, Antipho, it's he trifling with me, for he knew me to be a person of this sort; I supposed him to be quite a different man; he has deceived me; I'm not a bit different to him from what I was before. But however that may be, I'll yet do this; the captain has said, that to-morrow morning he will pay me the money; if you bring it me before that, Phaedria, I'll follow my rule, that he is the first served who is the first to pay. Farewell! Goes into his house.

div2.stage: PHAEDRIA, ANTIPHO, and GETA.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What am I to do? Wretch that I am! where am I now in this emergency to raise the money for him, I, who am worse than nothing? If it had been possible for these three days to be obtained of him, it was promised me by then.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Geta, shall we suffer him to continue thus wretched, when he so lately assisted me in the kind way you were mentioning? On the contrary, why not, as there's need of it try to do him a kindness in return?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: For my part, I'm sure it is but fair.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Come then, you are the only man able to serve him.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What can I do?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Procure the money.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I wish I could; but where it is to come from--tell me that.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: My father has come home.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I know; but what of that?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Oh, a word to the wiseA word to the wise: "Dictum sapienti sat est." The same proverb is found in the Persa of Plautus, 1. 736. is quite enough.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Is that it, then?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Upon my faith, you really do give me fine advice; out upon you! Ought I not to be heartily glad, if I meet with no mishap through your marriage, but what, in addition to that, you must now bid me, for his sake, to be seeking risk upon risk?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: 'Tis true what he says.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What! am I a stranger to you, Geta?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I don't consider you so. But is it so trifling a matter that the old gentleman is now vexed with us all, that we must provoke him still more, and leave no room for entreaty?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Is another man to take her away from before my eyes to some unknown spot? Alas! speak to me then, Antipho, and look upon me while you have the opportunity, and while I'm present.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Why so, or what are you going to do? Pray, tell me.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: To whatever part of the world she is borne away, I'm determined to follow her or to perish.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: May the Gods prosper your design! Cautiously's the word, however.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: to GETA. Do see if you can give him any assistance at all.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Any at all--how?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Pray, do try, that he mayn't be doing something that we may afterward be more or less sorry for, Geta.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I'm considering, He pauses. He's all safe, so far as I can guess: but still, I'm afraid of mischief.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Don't be afraid: together with you, we'll share good and bad.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to PHAEDRIA. How much money do you want? Tell me.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Only thirty mince.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Thirty? Heyday! she's monstrous dear, Phaedria.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Indeed, she's very cheap.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Well, well, I'll get them for you.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Oh the dear man! They both fall to hugging GETA.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Take yourselves off. Shakes them of.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: There's need for them directly.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: You shall have them directly; but I must have Phormio for my assistant in this business.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: He's quite ready; right boldly lay on him any load you like, he'll bear it: he, in especial, is a friend to his friend.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Let's go to him at once then.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Will you have any occasion for my assistance?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: None; but be off home, and comfort that poor thing, who I am sure is now in-doors almost dead with fear. Do you linger?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: There's nothing I could do with so much pleasure. Goes into the house of DEMIPHO.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What way will you manage this?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I'll tell you on the road; first thing, betake yourself off. (Exeunt.)

div2.stage: Enter DEMIPHO and CHREMES.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well, have you brought your daughter with you, Chremes, for whom you went to Lemnos?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: When her mother found that I staid here longer than usual, and at the same time the age of the girl did not suit with my delays, they told me that she, with all her family, set out in search of me.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Pray, then, why did you stay there so long, when you had heard of this?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why, faith, a malady detained me.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: From what cause? Or what was it?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do you ask me? Old age itself is a malady. However, I heard that they had arrived safe, from the caps tain who brought them.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Have you heard, Chremes, what has happened to my son in my absence?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: 'Tis that, in fact, that has embarrassed me in my plans. For if I offer my daughter in marriage to any person that's a stranger, it must all be told how and by whom I had her. You I knew to be fully as faithful to me as I am to myself; if a stranger shall think fit to be connected with me by marriage, he will hold his tongue, just as long as good terms exist between us: but if he takes a dislike to me, he'll be knowing more than it's proper he should know. I am afraid, too, lest my wife should, by some means, come to know of it; if that is the case, it only remains for me to shake myselfTo shake myself: "Me excutiam." In reference to the custom of the Greeks, and the Eastern nations, of shaking their clothes at the door of any house which they were going to leave. and leave the house; for I'm the only one I can rely on at home.Rely on at home: "Nam ego meorum solus sum meus." He means that he is the only person in his house friendly to himself, inasmuch as his wife, from her wealth, has supreme power over the domestics, in whom he himself can place no trust.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I know it is so, and that circumstance is a cause of anxiety to me; and I shall never cease trying, until I've made good what I promised you.

div2.stage: Enter GETA, on the other side of the stage, not seeing DEMIPHO or CHREMES.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself. I never saw a more cunning fellow than this Phormio. I came to the fellow to tell him that money was needed, and by what means it might be procured. Hardly had I said one half, when he understood me; he was quite delighted; complimented me; asked where the old man was; gave thanks to the Gods that an opportunity was afforded him for showing himself no less a friend to Phaedria than to Antipho: I bade the fellow wait for me at the Forum; whither I would bring the old gentlemanly. But see, here's the very man catching sight of the Old Man. Who is the further one? Heyday, Phaedria's father has got back! still, brute beast that I am, what was I afraid of? Is it because two are presented instead of one for me to dupe? I deem it preferable to enjoy a two-fold hope. I'll try for it from him from whom I first intended: if he gives it me, well and good; if I can make nothing of him, then I'll attack this new-comer.

div2.stage: Enter ANTIPHO from the house, behind at a distance.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: to himself. I'm expecting every moment that Geta will be here. But I see my uncle standing close by, with my father. Ah me! how much I fear what influence his return may have upon my father!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself I'll accost them. Goes up to them. O welcome to you, our neighbor Chremes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Save you, Geta.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I'm delighted to see you safe returned.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I believe you.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: How go matters?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Many changes here upon my arrival, as usually the case.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: True; have you heard what has happened to Antipho?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to DEMIPHO. What, have you told him? Disgraceful conduct, Chremes, thus to be imposed on.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: It was about that I was talking to him just now.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: But really, on carefully reflecting upon this matter I think I have found a remedy.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What is the remedy?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: When I left you, by accident Phormio met me.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Who is Phormio?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He who patronized her.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: It seemed to me that I might first sound him; I took the fellow aside: "Phormio," said I, "why don't we try to settle these matters between us rather with a good grace than with a bad one? My master's a generous man, and one who hates litigation; but really, upon my faith, all his friends were just now advising him with one voice to turn her instantly out of doors."

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart. What is he about? Or where is this to end at last?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: continuing the supposed conversation. "He'll have to give satisfaction at law, you say, if he turns her out? That has been already inquired into: aye, aye, you'll have enough to do, if you engage with him; he is so eloquent. But suppose he's beaten; still, however, it's not his life, but his money that's at stake." After I found that the fellow was influenced by these words, I said: "We are now by ourselves here; come now, what should you like to be given you, money down, to drop this suit with my master, so that she may betake herself off, and you annoy us no more?"

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart. Are the Gods quite on good terms with him?Good terms with him: Meaning, "Is he in his senses or not?"

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: continuing the conversation. "For I'm quite sure, if you were to mention any thing that's fair and reasonable, as he is a reasonable man, you'll not have to bandy three words with him."

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Who ordered you to say so?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nay, he could not have more happily contrived to bring about what we want.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart. Undone!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Go on with your story.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: At first the fellow raved.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Say, what did he ask?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What? A great deal too much.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: How much? Tell me.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Suppose he were to give a great talent.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Aye, faith, perdition to him rather; has he no shame?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Just what I said to him: "Pray," said I, "suppose he was portioning an only daughter of his own. It has been of little benefit that he hasn't one of his own, when another has been found to be demanding a fortune." To be brief, and to pass over his impertinences, this at last was his final answer: "I," said he," from the very first, have been desirous to marry the daughter of my friend, as was fit I should; for I was aware of the ill results of this, a poor wife being married into a rich family, and becoming a slave. But, as I am now conversing with you unreservedly, I was in want of a wife to bring me a little money with which to pay off my debts; and even yet, if Demipho is willing to give as much as I am to receive with her to whom I am engaged, there is no one whom I should better like for a wife."

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart. Whether to say he's doing this through folly or mischief, through stupidity or design, I'm in doubt.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What if he's in debt to the amount of his life?Amount of his life: "Quid si animam debet?" Erasmus tells us that this was a proverb among the Greeks applied to those who ran so deeply in debt, that their persons, and consequently, in one sense, their very existence, came into the power of their creditors.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: His land is mortgaged,--for ten minae he said.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well, well, let him take her then; I'll give it.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He has a house besides, mortgaged for another ten.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Huy, huy! that's too much.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Don't be crying out; you may have those ten of me.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: A lady's maid must be brought for his wife; and then too, a little more is wanted for some furniture, and some is wanted for the wedding expenses. " Well then," said he, "for these items, put down ten more."

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Then let him at once bring six hundred actionsSix hundred actions: "Sescentos;" literally, "six hundred." The Romans used this term as we do the words "ten thousand," to signify a large, but indefinite number. against me; I shall give nothing at all; is this dirty fellow to be laughing at me as well?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Pray do be quiet; I'll give it: do you only bring your son to marry the woman we want him to have.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart. Ah me! Geta, you have ruined me by your treachery.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: 'Tis on my account she's turned off; it's right that I should bear the loss.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: " Take care and let me know," said he, "as soon as possible, if they are going to let me have her, that I may get rid of the other, so that I mayn't be in doubt; for the others have agreed to.pay me down the portion directly."

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Let him have her at once; let him give notice to them that he breaks off the match with the other, and let him marry this woman.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Yes, and little joy to him of the bargain!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Luckily, too, I've now brought home some money with me, the rents which my wife's farms at Lemnos produce. I'll take it out of that, and tell my wife that you had occasion for it. They go into the house of CHREMES.

div2.stage: ANTIPHO and GETA.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: coming forward. Geta.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What have you been doing?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Diddling the old fellows out of their money.
