sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Is that quite the thing?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I' faith, I don't know: it's just what I was told to do.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: How now, whip-scoundrel, do you give me an answer to what I don't ask you? Kicks him.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: What was it then that you did ask?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What was it I did ask? Through your agency, matters have most undoubtedly come to the pass that I may go hang myself. May then all the Gods, Goddesses, Deities above and below, with every evil confound you! Look now, if you wish any thing to succeed, intrust it to him who may bring you from smooth water on to a rock. What was there less advantageous than to touch upon this sore, or to name my wife? Hopes have been excited in my father that she may possibly be got rid of. Pray now, tell me, suppose Phormio receives the portion, she must be taken home by him as his wife: what's to become of me?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: But he's not going to marry her.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I know that. But ironically when they demand the money back, of course, for our sake, he'll prefer going to prison.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: There is nothing, Antipho, but what it may be made worse by being badly told: you leave out what is good, and you mention the bad. Now then, hear the other side: if he receives the money, she must be taken as his wife, you say; I grant you; still, some time at least will be allowed for preparing for the nuptials, for inviting, and for sacrificing. In the mean time, Phoedria's friends will advance what they have promised; out of that he will repay it.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: On what grounds? Or what will he say?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Do you ask the question? "How many circumstances, since then, have befallen me as prodigies? A strange black dogA strange black dog: This omen, Plautus calls, in the Casina, 1. 937, "canina scaeva." entered the house; a snake came down from the tiles through the sky-light;Through the sky-light: So in the Amphitryon of Plautus, l. 1108, two great snakes come down through the "impluvium," or "sky-light." On the subject of the "impluvium," see the Notes to the Miles Gloriosus of Plautus, 1. 159. a hen crowed;A hen crowed: Donatus tells us that it was a saying, that in the house where a hen crowed, the wife had the upper hand. the soothsayer forbade it; the divinerThe soothsayer--the diviner: According to some accounts there was this difference between the "hariolus" and the " arus-pex," that the former foretold human events, the latter those relating to the Deities. Donatus has remarked on these passages, that Terence seems to sneer at the superstitions referred to. warned me not: besides, before winter there is no sufficient reason for me to commence upon any new undertaking." This will be the case.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I only wish it may be the case.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: It shall be the case; trust me for that. Your father's coming out; go tell Phaedria that the money is found.

div2.stage: Enter DEMIPHO and CHREMES, from the house of the latter, the former with a purse of money.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Do be quiet, I tell you; I'll take care he shall not be playing any tricks upon us. I'll not rashly part with this without having my witnesses; I'll have it stated to whom I pay it, and for what purpose I pay it.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: apart. How cautious he is, when there's no need for it!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why yes, you had need do so, and with all haste, while the fit is upon him; for if this other woman shall prove more pressing, perhaps he may throw us over.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: You've hit upon the very thing.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Lead me to him then.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I won't delay.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to DEMIPHO. When you've done so, go over to my wife, that she may call upon her before she goes away. She must tell her that we are going to give her in marriage to Phormio, that she may not be angry with us; and that he is a fitter match for her, as knowing more of her; that we have in no way departed from our duty; that as much has been given for a portion as he asked for.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What the plague does that matter to you?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: A great deal, Demipho. It is not enough for you to do your duty, if common report does not approve of it; I wish all this to be done with her own sanction as well, that she mayn't be saying that she has been turned out of doors.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I can do all that myself.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It will come better from one woman to another.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I'll ask her. Goes into the house of CHREMES; and exit GETA.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to himself. I'm thinking where I can find them now.Can find them now: His Lemnian wife and daughter. Colman remarks: " This is intended as a transition to the next Scene; but I think it would have been better if it had followed without this kind of introduction. The Scene itself is admirable, and is, in many places, both affecting and comic, and the discovery of the real character of Phanium is made at a very proper time."

div2.stage: Enter SOPHRONA from the house of DEMIPHO, at a distance.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: to herself. What am I to do? What friend, in my distress, shall I find, to whom to disclose these plans; and where shall I look for relief? For I'm afraid that my mistress, in consequence of my advice, may undeservingly sustain some injury, so extremely ill do I hear that the young man's father takes what has happened.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart, to himself. But what old woman's this, that has come out of my brother's house, half dead with fright?

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: to herself, continuing It was distress that compelled me to this step, though I knew that the match was not likely to hold good; my object was, that in the mean time life might be supported.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart, to himself. Upon my faith, surely, unless my recollection deceives me, or my sight's not very good, I espy my daughter's nurse.My daughter's nurse: Among the ancients, it was the custom for nurses who had brought up children to remain with them in after-life.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: to herself. And we are not able to find----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. What must I do?

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: to herself. Her father.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to himself, apart. Shall I accost her, or shall I wait to learn more distinctly what it is she's saying?

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: to herself If now I could find him, there's nothing that I should be in fear of.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart, to himself, aloud. 'Tis the very woman. I'll address her.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: turning round. Who's that speaking here?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: coming forward. Sophrona.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Mentioning my name, too?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Look round at me.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: seeing him. Ye Gods, I do beseech you, isn't this Stilpho?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Do you deny it?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: in a low voice. Step a little this way from that door, Sophrona, if you please pointing. Don't you, henceforth, be calling me by that name.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Why? Pray, are you not the person you always used to say you were?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Hush! pointing to his own house.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Why are you afraid about that door?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: in a low voice. I have got a shrew of a wife shut up there. For by that name I formerly falsely called myself, in order that you might not chance indiscreetly to blab it out of doors, and then my wife, by some means or other, might come to know of it.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: I' faith, that's the very reason why we, wretched creatures, have never been able to find you out here.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Well, but tell me, what business have you with that family from whose house you were coming out? Where are the ladies?Where are the ladies?: "Ubi illae?" literally, "Where are these women?"

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Ah, wretched me!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Hah! What's the matter? Are they still alive?

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Your daughter is alive. Her poor mother died of grief.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: An unfortunate thing!

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: As for me, being a lone old woman, in want, and unknown, I contrived, as well as I could, to get the young woman married to the young man who is master of this house pointing.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What! to Antipho?

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: The very same, I say.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What? Has he got two wives?

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Dear no, prithee, he has only got this one.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What about the other one that's called his relative?

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Why, this is she.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: It was done on purpose, in order that her lover might be enabled to marry her without a portion.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Ye Gods, by our trust in you! How often do those things come about through accident, which you couldn't dare to hope for? On my return, I have found my daughter matched with the very person I wished, and just as I wanted; a thing that we were both using our endeavors, with the greatest earnestness, to bring about. Without any very great management on our part, by her own management, she has by herself brought this about.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: Now consider what's to be done. The young man's father has returned, and they say that he bears this with feelings highly offended.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: There's no danger of that. But, by Gods and men, do take care that no one comes to know that she's my daughter.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: No one shall know it from me.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Follow me; in-doors we'll hear the rest. He goes into DEMIPHO'S house, followed by SOPHRONA.

div2.stage: Enter DEMIPHO and GETA.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: 'Tis caused by our own fault, that it is advantageous to be dishonest; while we wish ourselves to be styled very honest and generous. "So run away as not to run beyond the house,"Run beyond the house: "Fugias ne printer casam." This passage, has given much trouble to the Commentators; but it is pretty clear that the explanation of Donatus is the correct one: "Don't abandon your own home," that being the safest place. Stallbaum agrees with Gronovius in thinking that it was first applied as a piece of advice to runaway slaves, as being likely to become worse off by the change; probably much in the same spirit as we say, "Out of the frying-pan into the fire." as the saying is. Was it not enough to receive an injury from him, but money must be voluntarily offered him as well, that he may have something on which to subsist while he plans some other piece of roguery?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Most clearly so.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: They now get rewarded for it, who confound right with wrong.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Most undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: How very foolishly, in fact, we have managed the affair with him!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: If by these means we can only manage for him to marry her.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Is that, then, a matter of doubt?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I' faith, judging from what the fellow is, I don't know whether he mightn't change his mind.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: How! change it indeed?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I don't know: but "if perhaps," I say.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I'll do as my brother advised me, bring hither his wife, to talk with her. Do you, Geta, go before; tell her that Nausistrata is about to visit her. DEMIPHO goes into the house of CHREMES.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: The money's been got for Phaedria; it's all hushed about the lawsuit; due care has been taken that she's not to leave for the present. What next, then? What's to be done? You are still sticking in the mud. You are paying by borrowing;Paying by borrowing: "Versura solvere," was "to pay a debt by borrowing money," and consequently to be no better off than before. Geta having, by the money he has procured, freed Phaedria from all danger of losing his mistress, but at the same time having brought Antipho into still greater danger of losing his wife. the evil that was at hand, has been put off for a day. The toils are increasing upon you, if you don't look out. Now I'll away home, and tell Phanium not to be afraid of Nausistrata, or his talking.Or his talking: "Ejus" here alludes, not to Nausistrata but to Phormio. Madame Dacier suggests that it should be "hujus." Goes into the house of DEMIPHO.

div2.stage: Enter DEMIPHO and NAUSISTRATA, from the house of CHREMES.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Come now, Nausistrata, after your usual way, manage to keep her in good-humor with us, and make her do of her own accord what must be done.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: You are now seconding me with your endeavors, just as you assisted me with your moneyWith your money: Colman observes: "Alluding to the money borrowed of her to pay Phormio; and as Donatus observes in another place, it is admirably contrived, in order to bring about a humorous catastrophe that Chremes should make use of his wife's money on this occasion.' before.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: I wish to do so; and yet, i' faith, through the fault of my husband, I am less able than I ought to be.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Because, i' faith, he takes such indifferent care of the property that was so industriously acquired by my father; for from those farms he used regularly to receive two talents of silver yearly; there's an instance, how superior one man is to another.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Two talents, pray?

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Aye, and when things were much worse, two talents even.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Whew!

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: What! does this seem surprising?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Of course it does.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: I wish I had been born a man; Id have shown----

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: That I'm quite sure of.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: In what way----

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Forbear, pray, that you may be able to do battle with her; lest she, being a young woman, may be more than a match for you.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p:
I'll do as you bid me; but I see my husband coming out of your house.
Enter CHREMES, hastily, from DEMIPHO'S house.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Ha! Demipho, has the money been paid him yet?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I took care immediately.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I wish it hadn't been paid him. On seeing NAUSISTRATA, aside.: Halloo, I espy my wife; I had almost said more than I ought.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why do you wish I hadn't, Chremes?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It's all right.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What say you? Have you been letting her know why we are going to bring her? pointing to NAUSISTRATA.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I've arranged it.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Pray, what does she say?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: She can't be got to leave.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why can't she?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Because they are fond of one another.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What's that to us?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart, to DEMIPHO. A great deal; besides that, I've found out that she is related to us.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart. What! You are mad, surely.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. So you will find; I don't speak at random; I've recovered my recollection.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart. Are you quite in your senses?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. Nay, prithee, do take care not to injure your kinswoman.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart. She is not.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. Don't deny it; her father went by another name; that was the cause of your mistake.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart. Did she not know who was her father?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. She did.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart. Why did she call him by another name?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart, frowning. Will you never yield to me, nor understand what I mean?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart. If you don't tell me of any thing----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: impatiently. Do you persist?

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: I wonder what all this can be.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: For my part, upon my faith, I don't know.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: whispering to him. Would you like to know? Then, so may Jupiter preserve me, not a person is there more nearly related to her than are you and I.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: starting. Ye Gods, by our trust in you! let's away to her; I wish for all of us, one way or other, to be sure about this going.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: stopping him. Ah!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: That you should put so little confidence in me!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Do you wish me to believe you? Do you wish me to consider this as quite certain? Very well, be it so. Well, what's to be done with our friend'sOur friend's: Chremes himself is so called, to deceive Nausistrata. daughter?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: She'll do well enough.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Are we to drop her, then?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: The other one to stop?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: You may go then, Nausistrata.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: I' faith, I think it better for all that she should remain here as it is, than as you first intended; for she seemed to me a very genteel person when I saw her. Goes into her house.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: looking at the door of his house. Has she shut the door yet?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Now she has.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: O Jupiter! the Gods do befriend us; I have found that it is my daughter married to your son.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Ha! How can that possibly be?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: This spot is not exactly suited for me to tell it you.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well then, step in-doors.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Hark, you, I don't wish our sons even to come to know of this. They go into DEMIPHO'S house.

div2.stage: Enter ANTIPHO.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I'm glad that, however my own affairs go, my brother has succeeded in his wishes. How wise it is to cherish desires of that nature in the mind, that when things run counter, you may easily find a cure for them! He has both got the money, and released himself from care; I, by no method, can extricate myself from these troubles; on the contrary, if the matter is concealed, I am in dread--but if disclosed, in disgrace. Neither should I now go home, were not a hope still presented me of retaining her. But where, I wonder, can I find Geta, that I may ask him what opportunity he would recommend me to take for meeting my father?

div2.stage: Enter PHORMIO, at a distance.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to himself I received the money; handed it over to the Procurer; brought away the woman, that Phaedria might have her as his own--for she has now become free. Now there is one thing still remaining for me to manage,--to get a respite from the old gentlemen for carousing; for I'll enjoy myself the next few days.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: But here's Phormio. Going up to him. What have you to say?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: About what?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Why--what's Phaedria going to do now? In what way does he say that he intends to take his fill of love?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: In his turn, he's going to act your part.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What part?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: To run away from his father; he begs that you in your return will act on his behalf--to plead his cause for him. For he's going to carouse at my house. I shall tell the old man that I'm going to Sunium, to the fair, to purchase the female servant that Geta mentioned a while since, so that, when they don't see me here, they mayn't suppose that I'm squandering their money. But there is a noise at the door of your house.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: See who's coming out.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: It's Geta.

div2.stage: Enter GETA, at a distance, hastily, from the house of DEMIPHO.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself. O fortune! O good luck!O good luck: "Fors fortuna," "good fortune;" while "fortuna" merely means "chance." with blessings how great, how suddenly hast thou loaded this day with thy favors to my master Antipho!----

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart to PHORMIO. I wonder what it is he means.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: continuing. And relieved us, his friends, from alarm; but I'm now delaying, in not throwing my cloakThrowing my cloak: When expedition was required, it was usual to throw the ends of the "pallium," or "cloak," over the shoulders. over my shoulder throws it over his shoulder, and making haste to find him, that he may know what has happened.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart to PHORMIO. Do you understand what he's talking about?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: apart to ANTIPHO. Do you?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: apart to PHORMIO. Not at all.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: apart to ANTIPHO. And I just as much.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: to himself. I'll be off hence to the Procurer's; they are there just now. Runs along.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: calling out. Halloo! Geta!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: still running. There's for you. Is it any thing new or wonderful to be called back, directly you've started?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Geta!

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Do you persist? Troth, you shall not on this occasion get the better of me by your annoyance.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: running after him. Won't you stop?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: You'll be getting a beating.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Assuredly that will befall yourself just now unless you stop, you whip-knave.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: This must be some one pretty familiar, threatening me with a beating. Turns round. But is it the person I'm in search of or not? 'Tis the very man! Up to him at once.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: O being most blessed of all men living! For without question, Antipho, you are the only favorite of the Gods.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: So I could wish; but I should like to be told why I'm to believe it is so.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Is it enough if I plunge you into a sea of joy?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: You are worrying me to death.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Nay but do have done with your promises, and tell us what you bring.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: looking round. Oh, are you here too, Phormio?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: I am: but why do you delay?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Listen, then. When we just now paid you the money at the Forum, we went straight to Chremes; in the mean time, my master sent me to your wife.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I'll omit telling you that, as it is nothing to the present purpose, Antipho. Just as I was going to the woman's apartments, the boy Mida came running up to me, and caught me behind by my cloak, and pulled me back; I turned about, and inquired for what reason he stopped me; he said that it was forbidden for any one to go in to his mistress. "Sophrona has just now," said he, "introduced here Chremes, the old gentleman's brother," and he said that he was then in the room with them: when I heard this, on tip-toe I stole softly along; I came there, stood, held my breath, I applied my ear, and so began to listen, catching the conversation every word in this fashion shows them.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Well done, Geta.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Here I overheard a very pretty piece of business; so much so that I had nearly cried out for joy.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: laughing. What do you think?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Why, something most marvelous. Your uncle has been discovered to be the father of your wife, Phanium.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: starting. Ha! what's that you say

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: He formerly cohabited secretly with her mother at Lemnos.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: A dream: how could she be ignorant about her own father?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Be sure, Phormio, that there is some reason: but do you suppose that, outside of the door, I was able to understand every thing that passed between them within?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: On my faith, I too have heard the same story.

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: Aye, and I'll give you still further reason for believing it: your uncle in the mean time came out from there; not long after he returned again, with your father; each said that he gave you permission to retain her; in fine, I've been sent to find you, and bring you to them.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Why then carry me offCarry me off: Madame Dacier says that Antipho is so rejoiced here at Geta's news, that he jumps upon his shoulders, and is carried off in triumph, which was a sort of stage-trick, and was very diverting to the Audience. On this, Colman observes: "I believe Madame Dacier has not the least foundation for this extraordinary piece of information; and I must confess, that I have too high an opinion, both of the Roman audience and actors, to believe it to be true." at once;--why do you delay?

sp.speaker: GETA
sp.p: I'll do so.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: O my dear Phormio, farewell!

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Farewell, Antipho. ANTIPHO and GETA go into DEMIPHO'S house.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: So may the Gods bless me, this has turned out luckily. I'm glad of it, that such good fortune has thus suddenly befallen them. I have now an excellent opportunity for diddling the old men, and ridding Phaedria of all anxiety about the money, so that he mayn't be under the necessity of applying to any of his companions. For this same money, as it has been given him, shall be given for good, whether they like it or not: how to force them to this, I've fund out the very way. I must now assume a new air and countenance. But I'll betake myself off to this next alley; from that spot I'll present myself to them, when they come out of doors. I sha'n't go to the fair, where I pretended I was going. He retires into the alley.

div2.stage: Enter DEMIPHO and CHREMES, from DEMIPHO'S house.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I do give and return hearty thanks to the Gods, and with reason, brother, inasmuch as these matters have turned out for us so fortunately. We must now meet with Phormio as soon as possible, before he squanders our thirty minae, so that we may get them from him. Enter PHORMIO, coming forward, and speaking aloud, as though not seeing them.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: I'll go see if Demipho's at home; that as to whatThat as to what: Lemaire suggests that he is about to say: "that as to what was agreed upon between us, I may take home this young woman, and make her my wife."----

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: accosting him. Why, Phormio, we were coming to you.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Perhaps about the very same affair. DEMIPHO nods assent. I' faith, I thought so. What were you coming to my house for? Ridiculous; are you afraid that I sha'n't do what I have once undertaken? Hark you, whatever is my poverty, still, of this one thing I have taken due care, not to forfeit my word.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to DEMIPHO. Is she not genteel-looking,Is she not genteel-looking: Patrick has the following note here: "One can not conceive any thing more happy or just than these words of Chremes. Demipho's thoughts are wholly taken up how to recover the money, and Phormio is equally solicitous to retain it; but Chremes, who had just left his daughter, is regardless of their discourse, and fresh from the impressions which she had made on him, longs to know if his brother's sentiments of her were equally favorable, and naturally puts this paternal question to him." just as I told you?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Very much so.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: And this is what I'm come to tell you, Demipho, that I'm quite ready; whenever you please, give me my wife. For I postponed all my other business, as was fit I should, when I understood that you were so very desirous to have it so.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: pointing to CHREMES. But he has dissuaded me from giving her to you. "For what," says he, "will be the talk among people if you do this? Formerly, when she might have been handsomely disposed of, then she wasn't given; now it's a disgrace for her to be turned out of doors, a repudiated woman;" pretty nearly, in fact, all the reasons which you yourself, some little time since, were urging to me.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Upon my faith, you are treating me in a very insulting manner.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Do you ask me? Because I shall not be able to marry the other person I mentioned; for with what face shall I return to her whom I've slighted?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Then besides, I see that Antipho is unwilling to part with her. Aside, prompting DEMIPHO. Say so.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Then besides, I see that my son is very unwilling to part with the damsel. But have the goodness to step over to the Forum, and order this money to be transferred to my account,Transferred to my account: "Rescribere argentum," or "nummos," meant "to transfer," or "set down money to the account of another person in one's banker's books." A passage in the Asinaria of Plautus, l. 445, seems to have the same meaning. Phormio.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: What, when I've paid it over to the persons to whom I was indebted?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What's to be done, then?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: If you will let me have her for a wife, as you promised, I'll take her; but if you prefer that she should stay with you, the portion must stay with me, Demipho. For it isn't fair that I should be misled for you, as it was for your own sakes that I broke off with the other woman, who was to have brought me a portion just as large.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Away with you to utter perdition, with this swaggering, you vagabond. What, then, do you fancy we don't know you, or your doings?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: You are provoking me.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Would you have married her, if she had been given to you?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Try the experiment.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: That my son might cohabit with her at your house, that was your design.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Pray, what is that you say?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Then do you give me my money?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Nay, but do you give me my wife?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Come before a magistrate. Going to seize hold of him.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Why, really, if you persist in being troublesome--

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: What, I? You fancy, perhaps, just now, that I am the protector of the portionless; for the well portioned,For the well portioned: Though Colman thinks otherwise, it is pretty clear that he alludes to Nausistrata in these words. I'm in the habit of being so as well.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What's that to us?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: with a careless air. Nothing at all. I know a certain lady here pointing at CHREMES'S house whose husband had----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: starting. Ha!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Another wife at Lemnos----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: aside. I'm ruined!

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: By whom he had a daughter; and her he is secretly bringing up.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: aside. I'm dead and buried!

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: This I shall assuredly now inform her of. Walks toward the house.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: running and catching hold of him. I beg of you, don't do so.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: with a careless air. Oh, were you the person?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What a jest he's making of us.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to PHORMIO. We'll let you off.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Nonsense.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What would you have? We'll forgive you the money you've got,

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: I hear you. Why the plague, then, do you two trifle with me in this way, you silly men, with your childish speeches--"I won't, and I will; I will, and I won't," over again: "keep it, give it me back; what has been said, is unsaid; what had been just a bargain, is now no bargain."

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: aside, to DEMIPHO. In what manner, or from whom has he come to know of this?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: aside. I don't, know; but that I've told it to no one, I know for certain.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: aside. So may the Gods bless me, 'tis as good as a miracle.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: aside, to himself. I've graveled them.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart, to CHREMES. Well now, is he to be carrying offTo be carrying off: Patrick has the following note here: "The different characters of the two brothers are admirably preserved throughout this Scene. Chremes stands greatly in awe of his wife, and will submit to any thing rather than the story should come to her ears; but Demipho can not brook the thoughts of losing so much money, and encourages his brother to behave with spirit and resolution, promising to make up matters between him and his wife." from us such a sum of money as this, and so palpably to impose upon us? By heavens, I'd sooner die. Manage to show yourself of resolute and ready wit. You see that this slip of yours has got abroad, and that you can not now possibly conceal it from your wife; it is then more conducive to our quiet, Chremes, ourselves to disclose what she will be hearing from others; and then, in our own fashion, we shall be able to take vengeance upon this dirty fellow.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: aside, to himself. Good lack-a-day, now's the sticking-point, if I don't look out for myself. They are making toward me with a gladiatorial air.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart, to DEMIPHO. But I doubt whether it's possible for her to be appeased.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart, to CHREMES. Be of good courage; I'll effect a reconciliation between you; remembering this, Chremes, that she is dead and goneDlead and gone: "E medio excedere," was an Euphemism signifying "to die," which it was deemed of ill omen to mention. by whom you had this girl.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: in a loud voice. Is this the way you are going to deal with me? Very cleverly done. Come on with you. By heavens, Demipho, you have provoked me, not to his advantage pointing at CHREMES. How say you? addressing CHREMES. When you've been doing abroad just as you pleased, and have had no regard for this excellent lady here, but on the contrary, have been injuring her in an unheard-of manner, would you be coming to me with prayers to wash away your offenses? On telling her of this, I'll make her so incensed with you, that you sha'n't quench her, though you should melt away into tears.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: aside. A plague may all the Gods and Goddesses send upon him. That any fellow should be possessed of so much impudence! Does not this villain deserve to be transported hence to some desolate land at the public charge?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: aside. I am brought to such a pass, that I really don't know what to do in it.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I know; let's go into court.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Into court? Here in preference pointing to CHREMES'S house, if it suits you in any way. Moves toward the house.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to CHREMES. Follow him, and hold him back, till I call out the servants.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: trying to seize PHORMIO. But I can't by myself; run and help me.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to DEMIPHO, who seizes hold of him. There's one action of damages against you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Sue him at law, then.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: And another with you, Chremes.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Lay hold of him. They both drag him.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Is it thus you do? Why then I must exert my voice: Nausistrata, come out calling aloud.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to DEMIPHO. Stop his mouth.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: See how strong the rascal is.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: calling aloud. Nausistrata, I say.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Will you not hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Hold my tongue?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to CHREMES, as they drag him along. If he won't follow, plant your fists in his stomach.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Or e'en gouge out an eye. The time's coming when I shall have a full revenge on you.

div2.stage: Enter NAUSISTRATA, in haste, from the house.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Who calls my name?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: in alarm. Ha!

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: My husband, pray what means this disturbance?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to CHREMES. Oh, oh, why are you mute now?

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Who is this man? Won't you answer me?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: What, he to answer you? who, upon my faith, doesn't know where he is.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to NAUSISTRATA. Take care how you believe that fellow in any thing.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to NAUSISTRATA. Go, touch him; if he isn't in a cold sweat all over, why then kill me.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: 'Tis nothing at all.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: What is it, then, that this person is talking about?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: You shall know directly; listen now.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Are you resolved to believe him?

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Pray, how can I believe him, when he has told me nothing?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: The poor creature is distracted from fright.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: It isn't for nothing, i' faith, that you are in such a fright.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What, I in a fright?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to CHREMES. All right, of course: since you are not in a fright at all, and this is nothing at all that I'm going to tell, do you relate it.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Villain, is he to relate it at your request?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to DEMIPHO. Come now, you've managed nicely for your brother.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: My husband, will you not tell me?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: But----

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: There's no need to tell you.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Not for you, indeed; but there's need for her to know it. At Lemnos----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: starting. Ha! what are you doing?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to PHORMIO. Won't you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: to NAUSISTRATA. Unknown to you----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Ah me!

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: He married another----

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: My dear sir, may the Gods forbid it!

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Such is the fact.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Wretch that I am, I'm undone!

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: And had a daughter by her, too, while you never dreamed of it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What are we to do?

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: O immortal Gods!--a disgraceful and a wicked misdeed!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: aside, to CHREMES. It's all up with you.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Was ever any thing now more ungenerously done? Your men, who, when they come to their wives, then become incapacitated from old age.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Demipho, I appeal to you; for with that man it is irksome for me to speak. Were these those frequent journeys and long visits at Lemnos? Was this the lowness of prices that reduced our rents?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Nausistrata, I don't deny that in this matter he has been deserving of censure; but still, it may be pardoned.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: apart. He is talking to the dead.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: For he did this neither through neglect or aversion to yourself. About fifteen years since, in a drunken fit, he had an intrigue with this poor woman, of whom this girl was born, nor did he ever touch her afterward. She is dead and gone: the only difficulty that remained in this matter. Wherefore, I do beg of you, that, as in other things, you'll bear this with patience.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Why should I with patience? I could wish, afflicted as I am, that there were an end now of this matter. But how can I hope? Am I to suppose that, at his age, he will not offend in future? Was he not an old man then, if old age makes people behave themselves decently? Are my looks and my age more attractive now, Demipho? What do you advance to me, to make me expect or hope that this will not happen any more?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: in a loud voice. Those who haveThose who have: He here uses the terms which it was customary to employ in the celebration of a public funeral. See also the form of proclaiming an auction, at the end of the Menaechmi of Plautus. a mind to come to the funeral of Chremes, why now's their time. 'Tis thus I retaliate: come now, let him challenge Phormio who pleases: I'll have him victimizedHave him victimized: "Mactatus" was the term applied to the pouring of wine and frankincense on the victim about to be sacrificed, on which it was said to be "magis auctus," "increased," or "amplified;" which, in time, became corrupted into the word "mactatus," or "mactus." with just a like mischance. Why then, let him return again into her good graces. I have now had revenge enough. She has got something for her as long as she lives, to be forever ringing into his ears.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: But it was because I deserved this, I suppose; why should I now, Demipho, make mention of each particular, how I have conducted myself toward him?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I know it all, as well as yourself.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Does it appear, then, that I deserved this treatment?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Far from it: but since, by reproaching, it can not now be undone, forgive him: he entreats you--he begs your pardon--owns his fault--makes an apology. What would you have more?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: aside. But really, before she grants pardon to him, I must take care of myself and Phaedria. To NAUSISTRATA. Hark you, Nausistrata, before you answer him without thinking, listen to me.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: I got out of him thirty minae by a stratagem. I give them to your son; he paid them to a Procurer for his mistress.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Ha! what is it you say?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: sneeringly. Does it seem to you so very improper for your son, a young man, to keep one mistress, while you have two wives? Are you ashamed of nothing? With what face will you censure him? Answer me that.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: He shall do as you wish.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Nay, that you may now know my determination, I neither forgive nor promise any thing, nor give any answer, before I see my son: to his decision I leave every thing. What he bids me, I shall do.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: You are a wise woman, Nausistrata.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Does that satisfy you, Chremes?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Yes, indeed, I come off well, and fully to my satisfaction; indeed, beyond my expectation.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: to PHORMIO. Do you tell me, what is your name?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: What, mine? Phormio; a well-wisher to your family, upon my honor, and to your son Phaedria in particular.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Then, Phormio, on my word, henceforward I'll both do and say for you all I can, and whatever you may desire.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: You speak obligingly.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: I' faith, it is as you deserve.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: First, then, will you do this, Nausistrata, at once, to please me, and to make your husband's eyes ache with vexation?

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Invite me to dinner.

sp.speaker: NAUSISTRATA
sp.p: Assuredly indeed, I do invite you.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Let us now away in-doors.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: By all means; but where is Phaedria, our arbitrator?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: I'll have him here just now. To the AUDIENCE. Fare you well, and grant us your applause.Grant us your applause: Thus concludes the last, and certainly not the least meritorious of the Plays of our Author; indeed, for genuine comic spirit, it may challenge comparison with the Eunuch, which is in general considered to be the best.

div2.stage: Enter PHAEDRIA and PHORMIO, from opposite sides of the stage.This scene is generally considered to be spurious.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Assuredly there is a God, who both hears and sees what we do. And I do not consider that to be true which is commonly said: "Fortune frames and fashions the affairs of mankind, just as she pleases."

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: aside. Heyday! what means this? I've met with Socrates, not Phaedria, so far as I see. Why hesitate to go up and address him? Accosting him. How now, Phaedria, whence have you acquired this new wisdom, and derived such great delight, as you show by your countenance?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: O welcome, my friend; O most delightful Phormio, welcome ! There's not a person in all the world I could more wish just now to meet than yourself.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Pray, tell me what is the matter.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Aye, faith, I have to beg of you, that you will listen to it. My Pamphila is a citizen of Attica, and of noble birth, and rich.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: What is it you tell me? Are you dreaming, pray?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Upon my faith, I'm saying what's true.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Yes, and this, too, is a true saying: " You'll have no great difficulty in believing that to be true, which you greatly wish to be so."

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Nay, but do listen, I beg of you, to all the wonderful things I have to tell you of. It was while thinking of this to myself, that I just now burst forth into those expressions which you heard--that we, and what relates to us, are ruled by the sanction of the Gods, and not by blind chance.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: I've been for some time in a state of suspense.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Do you know Phanocrates?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: As well as I do yourself.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: The rich man?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: He is the father of Pamphila. Not to detain you, these were the circumstances: Calchas was his servant, a worthless, wicked fellow. Intending to run away from the house, he carried off this girl, whom her father was bringing up in the country, then five years old, and, secretly taking her with him to Eubaea, sold her to Lycus, a merchant. This person, a long time after, sold her, when now grown up, to Dorio. She, however, knew that she was the daughter of parents of rank, inasmuch as she recollected herself being attended and trained up by female servants: the name of her parents she didn't recollect.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: How, then, were they discovered?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Stay; I was coming to that. This runaway was caught yesterday, and sent back to Phanocrates: he related the wonderful circumstances I have mentioned about the girl, and how she was sold to Lycus, and afterward to Dorio. Phanocrates sent immediately, and claimed his daughter; but when he learned that she had been sold, he came running to me.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: O, how extremely fortunate!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Phanocrates has no objection to my marrying her; nor has my father, I imagine.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Trust me for that; I'll have all this matter managed for you; Phormio has so arranged it, that you shall not be a suppliant to your father, but his judge.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You are joking.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: So it is, I tell you. Do you only give me the thirty minae which Dorio----

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You put me well in mind; I understand you; you may have them; for he must give them back, as the law forbids a free woman to be sold; and, on my faith, I do rejoice that an opportunity is afforded me of rewarding you, and taking a hearty vengeance upon him; a monster of a fellow he has feelings more hardened than iron.

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: Now, Phaedria, I return you thanks; I'll make you a return upon occasion, if ever I have the opportunity. You impose a heavy task upon me, to be contending with you in good offices, as I can not in wealth; and in affection and zeal, I must repay you what I owe. To be surpassed in deserving well, is a disgrace to a man of principle.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Services badly bestowed, I take to be disservices. But I do not know any person more grateful and more mindful of a service than yourself. What is it you were just now mentioning about my father?

sp.speaker: PHORMIO
sp.p: There are many particulars, which at present I have not the opportunity to relate. Let's go in-doors, for Nausistrata has invited me to dinner, and I'm afraid we may keep them waiting.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Very well; follow me. To the AUDIENCE. Fare you well, and grant us your applause.
